deadlineTip: ASAP — you’ll need proof you asked for repairs before filing.

title: File the LTB application
summary: Start an application for tenant rights/maintenance (commonly T2/T6).
actions: Complete LTB forms (T2: Tenant Rights; T6: Maintenance).
Attach evidence and your detailed timeline.

forms.name: LTB T2 — Application about Tenant Rights
LTB T6 — Tenant Application about Maintenance

deadlineTip: Some remedies are time-sensitive — file promptly.

title: Serve and prepare for the hearing
summary: Proper service and a clean evidence package matter.
actions: Serve as required; keep proof of service.
Organize exhibits, paginate, and prepare a short fact summary.

steps.title: Write down what happened and when
steps.summary: Map events, protected grounds, and adverse impacts.
actions: List dates, people involved, and witnesses.
Identify protected grounds (e.g., disability, family status).
steps.deadlineTip: HRTO has limitation periods — do not wait.

steps.title: Start your HRTO application
steps.summary: File Form 1 and Schedule A with facts and remedies sought.
actions: Complete the core application and attach Schedule A.
Describe remedies (monetary and non-monetary).
steps.deadlineTip: File before the deadline; extensions are discretionary.

steps.title: Determine if Small Claims is appropriate
steps.summary: Small Claims Court handles claims up to $35,000.
actions: Confirm your claim is $35,000 or less.
Ensure the defendant is in Ontario or the debt arose in Ontario.
Check if you have documentation of the debt.
steps.deadlineTip: You have 2 years from when the debt became due to file.

steps.title: File Form 7A - Plaintiff's Claim
steps.summary: Start your case by filing a plaintiff's claim.
actions: Complete Form 7A with details of your claim.
Include all supporting documents and evidence.
Pay the filing fee (varies by claim amount).
File at the Small Claims Court office.

steps.title: Serve the defendant
steps.summary: The defendant must receive proper notice of your claim.
actions: Serve the defendant personally or by alternative method.
Keep proof of service.
File proof of service with the court.
steps.deadlineTip: Serve within 6 months of issuing the claim.

steps.title: Await defendant's response or attend settlement conference
steps.summary: The defendant has 20 days to respond, then a settlement conference is scheduled.
actions: Wait for defendant's defence (Form 9A) if filed.
Attend mandatory settlement conference.
Bring all documents and be prepared to negotiate.
steps.deadlineTip: Settlement conference usually within 90 days of defence.

steps.title: Understand your charges
steps.summary: Review the charges and your legal options.
actions: Read your appearance notice or promise to appear carefully.
Note your first court date.
Consider contacting duty counsel or a lawyer.
steps.deadlineTip: Do not miss your first appearance date.

steps.title: Attend first appearance
steps.summary: Appear in court on your scheduled date.
actions: Arrive early and check in with court staff.
Speak with duty counsel if needed.
Enter your plea or request an adjournment.
steps.deadlineTip: Failure to appear can result in a warrant.

steps.title: Determine if you can appeal to the Supreme Court
steps.summary: Most cases require leave to appeal.
actions: Review if your case involves a constitutional question or significant legal issue.
Obtain the lower court decision and reasons.
Consult with an appellate lawyer - SCC cases are complex.
steps.deadlineTip: Application must be filed within 60 days of final judgment.

steps.title: File Application for Leave to Appeal
steps.summary: Apply for permission to bring your appeal to the SCC.
actions: Complete the Application Record Form.
Include memorandum of argument (max 40 pages).
Pay required filing fees.
Serve all parties.
